title: N2O5 and HNO3 Reaction and NH3 Buffer

content.question: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.Answer the following questions related to <math alttext="N 2 O 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>5</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="H N O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>HNO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>.(a) An incomplete Lewis diagram for <math alttext="N 2 O 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>5</mn></msub></math> is shown. Draw all of the remaining nonbonding electrons on the diagram.

You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.Answer the following questions related to <math alttext="N 2 O 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>5</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="H N O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>HNO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>.(a) An incomplete Lewis diagram for <math alttext="N 2 O 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>5</mn></msub></math> is shown. Draw all of the remaining nonbonding electrons on the diagram.

(b) Based on <math alttext="V S E P R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>VSEPR</mtext></math> theory and the molecular geometry around the central <math alttext="O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math> atom, what is the predicted <math alttext="N to O to N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math> bond angle?

When <math alttext="N 2 O 5, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mfenced><mi>g</mi></mfenced></math> is added to water, <math alttext="H N O 3, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>HNO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> is formed according to the following equation.<math alttext="N 2 O 5, gas plus H 2 O, liquid, reacts to produce 2 H N O 3, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi>HNO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mfenced><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></mfenced></math>Thermodynamic data for the reaction at <math alttext="298 kelvin" display="inline" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mo>°</mo></math>, in <math alttext="kilojoules per mole of reaction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></math>, at <math alttext="298 kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>298</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></math>.

(d) A student claims that lowering the temperature makes the value of <math alttext="delta G naught" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mo>°</mo></math> more negative. Do you agree or disagree? Justify your answer.

<math alttext="N 2 O 5, gas plus H 2 O, liquid, reacts to produce 2 H N O 3, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>+</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>→</mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi>HNO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>(e) Enough <math alttext="N 2 O 5, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mfenced><mi>g</mi></mfenced></math> is added to distilled water to make <math alttext="350, decimal point, milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>350.</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></math> of <math alttext="H N O 3, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>HNO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo> </mo><mfenced><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></mfenced></math>, as shown in the preceding equation. The resulting solution has a <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> of <math alttext="1.62" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.62</mn></math>.(i) Calculate the value of <math alttext="the molar concentration of H 3 O with a positive 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo>+</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></math> in the solution.

(ii) Assuming the <math alttext="H N O 3, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>HNO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> is produced with <math alttext="100%" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>100</mn><mo>%</mo></math> yield, calculate the mass of <math alttext="N 2 O 5, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>5</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> (molar mass <math alttext="108.02 grams per mole" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>108.02</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g/mol</mtext></math>) that was added in part (e).

(f) A buffer solution is prepared in a beaker as shown. Calculate the <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> of the solution in the beaker. The <math alttext="K a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mi mathvariant="italic">a</mi></msub></math> of <math alttext="N H 4 with a positive 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><msub><mi>NH</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mo>+</mo></msup></math> is <math alttext="5.6 times 10 to the negative 10 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5.6</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></msup></math>.

(g) Four students are each given a different beaker containing <math alttext="100.0 milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>100.0</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>mL</mtext></math> of a solution that contains <math alttext="0.75 molar N H 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.75</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mi>M</mi><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><msub><mi>NH</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="0.75 molar N H 4 N O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.75</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mi>M</mi><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><msub><mi>NH</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><msub><mi>NO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>. Each student adds a different amount of <math alttext="1.0 molar H N O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.0</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mi>M</mi><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><msub><mi>HNO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> and then correctly measures the <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>pH</mtext></math> of their solution, as shown in the overflow="scroll"><mn>80</mn><mo>.</mo></math><math alttext="1.56" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.56</mn></math>(i) Write a balanced net ionic equation for the reaction that occurs when a small amount of <math alttext="H N O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>HNO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> is added to Student A’s buffer solution.
(ii) What evidence in the data table indicates that the buffer capacity is exceeded only in the solution prepared by Student D?

skill.text: 1.A: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate particulate-level properties only.
